title: Desperate top-end buyers are 'paying over the odds'
text:
"Stock levels are very low. People want to put money into houses and not into the bank so they paying over the odds just to buy something, as we approach the end of the year.

"The flow-on effect is that no one is selling as there is no point in having cash in the bank," Ms Bloom said.

She gave as an example 23 Howitt Street in South Yarra, a three-bedroom Victorian terrace that sold under the hammer for $2.32 million through Marshall White.

"The vendor was selling this off-market four to five months ago and looking for $2.1 million. No one saw value at that level.

"But now he has got another $235,000 with five bidders competing. The buyer was an investor," Ms Bloom said.

Another example, she said, was the $6.3 million sale of 104 Caroline Street, also in South Yarra through Marshall White.

This three-bedroom Georgian home, sold vacant by a deceased estate and requiring extensive renovations, was quoted at $5 million to $5.5 million previously.

"Buyers are paying well over value," Ms Bloom said.

Advertisement

Penthouse tops prices

In Sydney, the most notable sale was not at auction, but off the plan, with a local resident buying a $140 million penthouse across the top three levels of Lendlease's One Sydney Harbour project at Barangaroo.

A rendering of the penthouse view from the yet-to-be-built Tower 1 in the One Sydney Harbour project. Supplied

The sale eclipsed the $100 million acquisition by tech billionaire Mike Cannon-Brookes and his wife Annie of the historic Fairwater estate at Point Piper little more than a year ago and the $60 million purchase two years ago by James Packer of a two-floor apartment in the Crown Sydney Residences.

The national preliminary auction clearance rate fell back to 75.6 per cent from almost 2000 auctions, according to CoreLogic.

This was down on last week's 77.3 per cent preliminary figure, later revised down to 73.5 per cent on a similar number of auctions. The same week last year, the clearance rate was just 46 per cent. Melbourne managed a 75.1 per cent preliminary clearance rate from more than 900 auctions, down on the 75.2 per cent final auction clearance last week when volumes were higher.

AMP Capital chief economist Dr Shane Oliver said sales volumes were up from lows, but still modest compared with 2013-17.

"Expect tight credit, unit supply and a soft economy to constrain prices after the initial bounce," he said.

Among the smaller auction markets, Canberra was the best performing with a preliminary auction clearance rate this week of 64.2 per cent, followed by Adelaide at 63.3 per cent.

Brisbane managed a preliminary clearance rate of just 50 per cent from 140 auctions, while Perth came in at 58.3 per cent with just 28 auctions.
description: Auction clearance rates eased back this week eliciting a warning about house prices running out of steam but at the top end of the market, investors are paying over the odds due a lack of stock.
